ray.rage.scene

Interface SceneManager

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Disposable
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    GenericSceneManager

    public interface SceneManager
extends Disposable
    A scene manager handles the creation, organization, and rendering of a scene, i.e., a collection of objects and potentially world geometry.

    Generally speaking, scene managers responsibilities include:

    • Creating and placing objects (e.g. cameras, scene-objects, etc.) in the scene so that they can be accessed efficiently (e.g. during graph traversal);
    • Loading and assembling world geometry, which is generally large/sprawling/static;
    • Implementing scene queries to answer questions about the contents or state of a scene;
    • Culling non-visible objects and placing visible ones into render-queues for rendering;
    • Setup and rendering of other objects in the scene (e.g. sky-boxes, lights, etc.);
    • Passing this organized content to a render-system for rendering;
    Author:
    Raymond L. Rivera

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Interface and Description
      static class  SceneManager.Environment
      The environment is the kind of world or setting the scene-manager is expected to handle.
      static interface  SceneManager.Listener
      A listener for scene-manager events.

      • destroyCamera

        void destroyCamera(java.lang.String name)
        Destroys the camera by the specified name, if it exists.

        The manager destroys the instance by removing it from its internal map and invoking its Disposable.notifyDispose() method.

        Parameters:
        name - The name of the camera to be destroyed.
        Throws:
        java.lang.RuntimeException - If no camera by the specified name exists.

      • createManualObject

        ManualObject createManualObject(java.lang.String name)
        Creates a new manual-object with the specified name.

        The mesh-manager used by this scene-manager must be used to create a manual mesh, with AbstractAssetManager.createManualAsset(String).

        It is the client's responsibility to explicitly set the program for the object after the sections have been created.

        Parameters:
        name - The name that will identify the new manual-object.
        Returns:
        A new manual-object.
        Throws:
        java.lang.RuntimeException - If the name already exists.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the name is empty.
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If the name is null.
        See Also:
        ManualObject.setGpuShaderProgram(GpuShaderProgram), Renderable.setGpuShaderProgram(GpuShaderProgram)

      • createTessellation

        Tessellation createTessellation(java.lang.String name,
                                int quality)
        Creates a new tessellation with the specified name.

        A quality level can be provided to specify the amount of vertices to be created for each patch during tessellation. A quality level 5 is the minimum; there is no maximum limit (thought it is recommended to not use values higher than 10).

        The number of primitives is determined by Math.Pow(2, quality), and the call to gl.glDrawArraysInstanced in GL4RenderSystem uses Math.Pow(2, quality) * Math.Pow(2, quality).

        Parameters:
        name - The name that will identify the new tessellation.
        quality - The degree of vertices to provide to each patch. A value of 6 to 10 is recommended.
        Returns:
        A new tessellation.
        Throws:
        java.lang.RuntimeException - If the name already exists.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the name is empty.
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If the name is null.

      • hasTessellation

        boolean hasTessellation(java.lang.String name)
        Checks whether this manager owns a tessellation with the specified name.

      • getRootSceneNode

        SceneNode getRootSceneNode()
        Gets the scene-node at the root of the scene graph.

        This method must always return the root scene-node. It's not allowed to throw exceptions or return a null value.

        Returns:
        The scene-node at the root of the scene graph.

      • createSceneNode

        SceneNode createSceneNode(java.lang.String name)
        Creates a new scene-node without adding it to the scene graph.

        A scene-node is said to be in the scene graph when it can trace its unbroken ancestry all the way up to the root scene-node. The scene-manager is still responsible for tracking and managing the new scene-node. However, the new scene-node will not have a parent; it must be explicitly assigned by the client.

        To add the scene-node to the graph after the fact, invoke Node.attachChild(Node) on the scene-node that should become the parent. For example: 

         parentNode.attachChild(childNode);
        Parameters:
        name - The name for the new scene-node.
        Returns:
        A new scene-node that is not part of the graph.

      • hasSceneNode

        boolean hasSceneNode(java.lang.String name)
        Checks whether a scene-node with the given name is owned by this scene-manager.
        Parameters:
        name - The name of the scene-node being checked.
        Returns:
        True if the scene-node exists. Otherwise false.

        void destroySceneNode(java.lang.String name)
        Destroys the scene-node by the specified name, if it exists.

        It's the scene-manager's responsibility to make sure the scene-node is detached from its direct parent, if any, and has all its scene-objects and child nodes removed.

        Parameters:
        name - The name of the scene-node to be destroyed.
        Throws:
        java.lang.RuntimeException - If no scene-node by the specified name exists.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the root scene-node is specified.

      • destroySceneNode

        void destroySceneNode(SceneNode sn)
        Destroys the scene-node by the specified name, if it exists.

        It's the scene-manager's responsibility to make sure the scene-node is detached from its direct parent, if any, and has all its scene-objects and child nodes removed.

        Parameters:
        sn - The scene-node to be destroyed.
        Throws:
        java.lang.RuntimeException - If no scene-node by the specified name exists.
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If the scene-node is null.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the root scene-node is specified.

      • getAmbientLight

        AmbientLight getAmbientLight()
        Gets the ambient-light that provides global scene illumination.

        The ambient-light is a singleton instance created by the scene-manager during initialization and is always available.

        Note that, due to the ambient-light's role in providing global illumination for a scene, it's not a scene-object.

        Returns:
        The ambient-light.

      • createLight

        Light createLight(java.lang.String name,
                  Light.Type type)
        Creates a new light of the specified type.

        NOTE: While the manager can, and does, support creating multiple lights, their number is currently limited to one because the underlying shader programs are not yet capable of supporting multiple sources simultaneously. This is expected to be a temporary limitation.

        Parameters:
        name - The name for the new light.
        type - The type of the new light.
        Returns:
        A new light.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the name is empty.
        java.lang.RuntimeException - If there's already another light by the same name.
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If any of the arguments is null.

      • hasLight

        boolean hasLight(java.lang.String name)
        Checks whether a light with the given name is owned by this scene-manager.
        Parameters:
        name - The name of the light being checked.
        Returns:
        True if the light exists. Otherwise false.

      • getLight

        Light getLight(java.lang.String name)
        Gets the light with the specified name, if it exists.
        Parameters:
        name - The name of the light.
        Returns:
        The light, if it exists. Otherwise null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.RuntimeException - If the manager does not own a light with the specified name.

      • getLights

        java.lang.Iterable<Light> getLights()
        Lets the caller iterate over all the lights owned by this manager.
        Returns:
        An Iterable of lights.

      • getLightCount

        int getLightCount()
        Gets the number of lights owned by this manager.
        Returns:
        The number of lights.

      • destroyLight

        void destroyLight(java.lang.String name)
        Destroys the light by the specified name, if it exists.

        The manager destroys the instance by removing it from its internal map and invoking its Disposable.notifyDispose() method.

        Parameters:
        name - The name of the light to be destroyed.
        Throws:
        java.lang.RuntimeException - If no light by the specified name exists.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the root light is specified.

      • destroyLight

        void destroyLight(Light l)
        Destroys the light by the specified name, if it exists.

        The manager destroys the instance by removing it from its internal map and invoking its Disposable.notifyDispose() method.

        Parameters:
        l - The light to be destroyed.
        Throws:
        java.lang.RuntimeException - If no light by the specified name exists.
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If the light is null.

      • destroyAllSceneObjects

        void destroyAllSceneObjects()
        Destroys all the scene-objects created by this scene-manager, except the root scene-node.

        All scene-objects destroyed during this process will need to be re-created by the client.

      • addController

        void addController(Node.Controller ctrl)
        Adds the specified controller to this scene-manager.
        Parameters:
        ctrl - The controller.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If the controller is null.

      • getController

        Node.Controller getController(int index)
        Gets the controller at the specified index, based on the order in which they were added.
        Parameters:
        index - The zero-based index of the controller's position.
        Returns:
        The controller at the specified index.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - If the index is out of the [0, size()) range.

      • getControllerCount

        int getControllerCount()
        Gets the number of controllers this scene-manager has.
        Returns:
        The number of controllers.

      • updateControllers

        void updateControllers(float elapsedTimeMillis)
        Invokes Node.Controller.update(float) on every controller this scene-manager has.
        Parameters:
        elapsedTimeMillis - The amount of time since the last update, in milliseconds.

      • getControllers

        java.lang.Iterable<Node.Controller> getControllers()
        Lets the caller iterate over all the controllers owned by this manager.
        Returns:
        An Iterable of controllers.

      • removeAllControllers

        void removeAllControllers()
        Removes all the controllers from this manager's control.

        The controllers are not destroyed; only removed. Updates must be done explicitly by the clients after this call.

      • updateSceneGraph

        void updateSceneGraph()
        Causes the scene graph to be updated and relevant listeners to be invoked.

        Specific scene-manager implementations should decide how to best do this.

      • renderScene

        void renderScene()
        Causes each camera known to this scene-manager to render the scene from its own point of view through its assigned viewport before asking the render-system to swap the back-buffer.

      • notifyRenderScene

        void notifyRenderScene(Camera camera,
                       Viewport viewport)
        Renders the scene from the viewpoint of the specified camera through the specified viewport.

        This method is internally invoked by each camera directly. This method is also responsible for emitting events for any registered render-queue-listeners and scene-manager-listeners.

        WARNING: This method is meant to be used internally by the framework and not by game clients. Use directly only if you really know what you're doing.

        Parameters:
        camera - The camera using this scene-manager to render the scene from its viewpoint.
        viewport - The viewport by which the specified camera is allowed to "look" at the scene.
        See Also:
        renderScene(), Camera.renderScene()

      • setRenderSystem

        void setRenderSystem(RenderSystem rs)
        Sets the render-system this scene-manager should submit its renderables to for processing.
        Parameters:
        rs - The render-system that will render the contents of the scene.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If the render-system is null.

      • getRenderSystem

        RenderSystem getRenderSystem()
        Gets the render-system currently in use by this scene-manager, if one has been set.
        Returns:
        The render-system, if any. Otherwise null.
